text: outlines propose change halfBaked. detailed discussion contributing tidyverse packages, please see development contributing guide code review principles.

title: Contributing to halfBaked
text: can fix typos, spelling mistakes, grammatical errors documentation directly using GitHub web interface, long changes made source file. generally means ’ll need edit roxygen2 comments .R, .Rd file. can find .R file generates .Rd reading comment first line.

title: Contributing to halfBaked
text: want make bigger change, ’s good idea first file issue make sure someone team agrees ’s needed. ’ve found bug, please file issue illustrates bug minimal reprex (also help write unit test, needed). See guide create great issue advice.

title: Contributing to halfBaked
text: Fork package clone onto computer. haven’t done , recommend using usethis::create_from_github("j-andrews7/halfBaked", fork = TRUE). Install development dependencies devtools::install_dev_deps(), make sure package passes R CMD check running devtools::check(). R CMD check doesn’t pass cleanly, ’s good idea ask help continuing. Create Git branch pull request (PR). recommend using usethis::pr_init("brief-description--change"). Make changes, commit git, create PR running usethis::pr_push(), following prompts browser. title PR briefly describe change. body PR contain Fixes #issue-number. user-facing changes, add bullet top NEWS.md (.e. just first header). Follow style described https://style.tidyverse.org/news.html.

title: Contributing to halfBaked
text: New code follow tidyverse style guide. can use styler package apply styles, please don’t restyle code nothing PR. use roxygen2, Markdown syntax, documentation. use testthat unit tests. Contributions test cases included easier accept.

title: Contributing to halfBaked
text: Please note halfBaked project released Contributor Code Conduct. contributing project agree abide terms.

title: Introduction to halfBaked
text: R open-source statistical environment can easily modified enhance functionality via packages. halfBaked R package available via Bioconductor repository packages. R can installed operating system CRAN can install halfBaked using following commands R session:
code: if (!requireNamespace("BiocManager", quietly = TRUE)) {     install.packages("BiocManager") }  BiocManager::install("halfBaked")  ## Check that you have a valid Bioconductor installation BiocManager::valid()

what: Study - Experiment - RNA-seq Data - Pin Generation
title: halfBaked RNA-seq Pin Generation Template
text: notebook details create re-usable easily shared pins RNA-seq data. pins contain SummarizedExperiment object containing gene counts TPMs along sample metadata. short, pretty much everything one need perform downstream analyses. convenience, ’ll also store experiment/dataset description, code used generate pin (.e. notebook). ’s recommended detail gene counts generated . typically use nf-core RNA-seq pipeline generate BAMs salmon quantifications, used generate gene counts appropriate downstream use. convenient samplesheets can double sample metadata tables . Noting pipeline version, genome information, altered parameters recommended. example, notebook details pin generation data GSE135880, processed nf-core RNA-seq pipeline:
code: nextflow run nf-core/rnaseq -r 3.12.0 -profile singularity -c "$BAKER_REF"/nf_configs/rnaseq.config -w /scratch_space/jandrews/"$LSB_JOBNAME" \ --outdir ./nfcore_mm10 --email jared.andrews@stjude.org --input nfcore_rnaseq.samplesheet.csv --gencode --genome MM10 --aligner star_salmon \ --pseudo_aligner salmon --max_memory 128.GB --skip_stringtie --max_multiqc_email_size 15.MB -resume

previous_headings: Study - Experiment - RNA-seq Data - Pin Generation
title: halfBaked RNA-seq Pin Generation Template
text: notebook uses YAML params header specify pin name board upload pin . allows easy re-use notebook different datasets boards lazy fashion. Read pins package don’t know “board” use .
code: params:   board: "your_server_info"   pin_name: "PinGen_Name_RNAseq_SummarizedExperiment_mm10"   pin_description: "A SummarizedExperiment containing O4+ immunopanned oligodendrocyte precursor cells (OPCs) from cortices of P5 or P6 Eed KO or control mice."

title: halfBaked RNA-seq Pin Generation Template
code: description <- "   **Study - SubStudy - Experiment - RNA-seq Data**    This dataset contains O4+ immunopanned oligodendrocyte precursor cells (OPCs) from cortices of P5 or P6 Eed KO or control mice.   See the [associated publication](https://www.science.org/doi/10.1126/sciadv.aaz6477) for more details.    Please see the Pin generation code to view how this data was processed.   "

title: halfBaked RNA-seq Pin Generation Template
code: library(SummarizedExperiment) library(readr) library(pins)  # Load sample metadata. meta <- read.csv("nfcore_rnaseq.samplesheet.csv", header = TRUE, stringsAsFactors = TRUE)  # Drop FASTQ file locations. meta <- meta[, !colnames(meta) %in% c("fastq_1", "fastq_2")]  # Load counts. This object was generated using tximport via the nf-core RNA-seq pipeline on the salmon quants and # is appropriate for pretty much all downstream DE packages (DESeq2, edgeR, limma). cts <- read.table("salmon.merged.gene_counts_length_scaled.tsv", header = TRUE, sep = "\t", stringsAsFactors = FALSE)  # nf-core RNA-seq pipeline generates a counts table with the first two columns as gene IDs and gene symbols. genes <- cts[, 1:2] rownames(cts) <- cts[, 1] cts <- cts[, -c(1:2)]  # Also carry along TPMs as an additional assay. tpms <- read.table("salmon.merged.gene_tpm.tsv", header = TRUE, sep = "\t", stringsAsFactors = FALSE) rownames(tpms) <- tpms[, 1] tpms <- tpms[, -c(1:2)]  # Set metadata rownames and ensure they match count column names. rownames(meta) <- meta$sample all(rownames(meta) == colnames(cts))  # Create a SummarizedExperiment object. se <- SummarizedExperiment(     assays = list(counts = as.matrix(cts),                   tpm = as.matrix(tpms),                   log2tpm = log2(as.matrix(tpms) + 1)),     colData = meta,     rowData = genes )

what: Add Metadata to Summarized Experiment and Upload Pin
title: halfBaked RNA-seq Pin Generation Template
code: # Render this notebook and add it to the metadata of the pin along with experiment metadata. pin_code <- read_file(rmarkdown::render("0.RNAseq_PinGen_Template.Rmd", quiet = TRUE)) metadata(se) <- list(pin_code = pin_code, description = description)  # Save the object locally as well. saveRDS(se, file = paste0(params$pin_name, ".rds"))  # Here you would connect to your board and write the pin to it. board <- board_connect(server = params$board) pin_write(board, se, type = "rds", name = params$pin_name, title = params$pin_name, description = params$pin_description)

title: Get DESeq2 Results — get_DESeq2_res
text: function obtains set comparisons DESeq2 analysis, given named list contrasts. allows additional model parameters specified design matrix manually adjusted.

title: Get DESeq2 Results — get_DESeq2_res
code: get_DESeq2_res(   dds,   contrasts,   res.list = list(),   user.mat = FALSE,   block = NULL,   design = NULL,   alpha = 0.05,   lfc.th = c(log2(1.25), log2(1.5)),   shrink.method = "ashr",   norm.ercc = FALSE,   add.rowData = NULL,   BPPARAM = NULL )

title: Get DESeq2 Results — get_DESeq2_res
text: dds object class DESeqDataSet. contrasts named list contrasts. res.list named list hold DESeq2 result tables. Allows function run multiple times needed append list. Defaults empty list. user.mat logical indicating whether user-specified model matrix provided. Defaults FALSE. block vector additional terms considered model, beyond main effect. Defaults NULL. design design formula matrix. matrix provided, ensure 'user.mat' set TRUE. Defaults NULL. alpha significance level hypothesis testing. Defaults 0.05. lfc.th numeric vector log2 fold-change thresholds. Defaults `c(log2(1.25), log2(1.5))“. shrink.method method used shrinkage estimation. Defaults "ashr". norm.ercc logical indicating whether normalize ERCC spike-ins. add.rowData vector column names rowData slot DESeqDataSet added results table. Defaults NULL. BPPARAM BiocParallelParam object specifying parallel back-end used. Defaults NULL.

title: Get DESeq2 Results — get_DESeq2_res
text: named list DESeq2::DESeqResults objects specified contrasts. add.rowData supplied, returned S4Vectors::DFrame objects instead.

title: Get DESeq2 Results — get_DESeq2_res
text: Jared Andrews

title: Get DESeq2 Results — get_DESeq2_res

To cite Bioconductor, see #>     'citation("Biobase")', and for packages 'citation("pkgname")'. #>  #> Attaching package: ‘Biobase’ #> The following object is masked from ‘package:MatrixGenerics’: #>  #>     rowMedians #> The following objects are masked from ‘package:matrixStats’: #>  #>     anyMissing, rowMedians dds_de <- makeExampleDESeqDataSet(n = 100, m = 12, betaSD = 2) # DE genes rownames(dds_de) <- paste0("gene", 1001:1100) dds <- makeExampleDESeqDataSet(n = 1000, m = 12) # Non-DE genes dds <- rbind(dds, dds_de) dds <- DESeq(dds) #> estimating size factors #> estimating dispersions #> gene-wise dispersion estimates #> mean-dispersion relationship #> final dispersion estimates #> fitting model and testing contrasts <- list("condition" = c("condition", "A", "B")) res <- get_DESeq2_res(dds, contrasts) #> Loading required package: ashr #>  #> Design for condition_A_vs_B is ~condition #> using pre-existing size factors #> estimating dispersions #> found already estimated dispersions, replacing these #> gene-wise dispersion estimates #> found already estimated gene-wise dispersions, removing these #> mean-dispersion relationship #> final dispersion estimates #> found already estimated dispersions, removing these #> fitting model and testing #> using 'ashr' for LFC shrinkage.
